context_text:
[Resolution] FTA eligibility information is not entered in WisE but is registered through the EPA field in Sales Contract on an item-by-item basis.

[Technical Diagnosis] The initial inquiry stemmed from a case in Thailand-India where incorrect FTA registration in the WisE master resulted in unnecessary import tax being paid. This prompted an investigation into whether FTA applied parts were correctly registered globally. The confusion arose because users were looking for FTA eligibility fields in WisE when they should have been using the EPA field in Sales Contract.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Recognize that FTA information is not entered directly in WisE system
2. Access the Sales Contract application instead of WisE for FTA registration
3. Locate the EPA field in Sales Contract (as shown in the attached JPG)
4. Register both FTA and COO (Certificate of Origin) information by item number in this EPA field
5. Note that this is a manual entry process with no specific documentation

[Strategic Note] To prevent future confusion and unnecessary import taxes, ensure all global teams are properly trained on the correct location and process for FTA/EPA registration in Sales Contract rather than looking for this functionality in WisE.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Decent coverage across question, ground truth, and RAG keywords

context_text:
[Resolution] The payment terms in JAST are determined by the trading partner code in Interface Mapping, not by the payment terms set in the WisE Contract Master.

[Technical Diagnosis] The customer was experiencing a discrepancy where they had set two different payment terms in WisE (BL180D for some customer codes and BLM090D for others), but when connected to JAST, all terms were showing as BL180D. Investigation revealed that while WisE displays the Contract Master's payment terms in invoice remarks, JAST receives payment terms based on the trading partner code registered in Interface Mapping, not from the WisE contract settings.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Verify the trading partner code registered in the current Contract (in this case A1981960).
2. Check the payment terms master registration for the corresponding code in Interface Mapping.
3. Note that for WisE invoices without a specification for the 1st line export entry number, the system will apply the payment term from the 2nd line (in this case, 06MGE).
4. To have different payment terms reflected in JAST, update the payment terms in Interface Mapping according to the appropriate trading partner codes.

[Strategic Note] For proper synchronization between WisE and JAST systems, always ensure that payment terms are correctly configured in Interface Mapping according to trading partner codes, as the Contract Master's payment terms in WisE only affect the invoice remarks and not the JAST integration.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: High coverage across question, ground truth, and RAG answer keywords

context_text:
[Resolution] Modify the GI sending timing settings at the contract level to ensure data is sent from WISE to WEST on the same day rather than defaulting to the next day.

[Technical Diagnosis] The issue occurred because the contract CNUSU500 was configured with the default setting that sends data from WISE to WEST on the next day, while other contracts had been reconfigured to send data on the same day. This inconsistency in configuration caused confusion when the user expected all contract data to be transmitted immediately but found that one specific contract's data was delayed.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Access the contract configuration settings for the specific contract (CNUSU500)
2. Locate the GI sending timing settings as documented in the 'Modify Send GI setting' reference document
3. Change the setting from the default next-day transmission to same-day transmission
4. Save the configuration changes
5. Verify that subsequent data transmissions appear in WEST reports on the same day they are processed in WISE

[Strategic Note] To prevent similar issues in the future, establish a standardized configuration review process for all contracts to ensure consistent GI sending timing settings across the system, especially when system-wide timing standards are modified.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Low question coverage but decent ground truth/RAG coverage

context_text:
[Resolution]: Update the Purchase Contract #4400003908 by entering the required Payment Terms to enable successful GR integration from WisE to WEST.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The system encountered an error during GR (Goods Receipt) integration from WisE to WEST because the target Purchase Contract (#4400003908) had blank Payment Terms, which is a required field for successful invoice registration in the WEST system. This prevented further processing in WEST, creating a business impact.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Identify the affected Purchase Contract (#4400003908) that's causing the integration error
2. Access the contract details in the system
3. Locate the Payment Terms field which is currently blank
4. Enter the appropriate Payment Terms information
5. Save the updated contract
6. Verify the GR integration process completes successfully
7. Confirm the invoice is properly registered in WEST

[Strategic Note]: To prevent similar integration errors in the future, implement validation checks during Purchase Contract creation to ensure critical fields like Payment Terms are never left blank before contracts are finalized.

context_text:
[Resolution] Process a backend WisE outbound operation after updating the WEST sales contract reference to the corrected number.

[Technical Diagnosis] The issue occurred when data transfer from WisE to WEST failed due to an error in the original WEST sales contract reference, preventing successful outbound processing and blocking invoice issuance to the customer. The customer had already created a new corrected sales contract (4400005635) and linked it in WisE, but the backend outbound processing needed to be triggered again to complete the data transfer.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Verify that the customer has created the new corrected WEST sales contract (in this case: 4400005635).
2. Confirm the new sales contract has been properly linked in the WisE system.
3. Have the system team process the WisE outbound operation again from the backend.
4. Instruct the user to verify successful data reception in the WEST system.

[Strategic Note] To prevent similar issues, implement a validation check for sales contract references during the initial setup process in WisE before outbound processing is attempted.

context_text:
[Resolution] The import HS code can be modified at the import TTC (Trade Transaction Center) as it is included in the Customer Contract.

[Technical Diagnosis] The user was unable to update import HS codes in the WisE contract master when collaborating with an importing country, as both the exporting country (where the user belongs) and the importing country reported they could not enter or record this information. The issue stemmed from a misunderstanding about which entity has the capability to modify import HS code data in the system.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Identify that the import HS code is part of the Customer Contract data structure
2. Contact the import TTC (Trade Transaction Center) with the updated HS code information
3. Request that they modify the import HS code in the WisE contract master
4. Verify the changes have been successfully implemented after the import TTC processes the update

[Strategic Note] For future HS code modifications, always direct requests to the import TTC rather than attempting updates through exporting countries, as the system architecture designates the import TTC as the authorized entity for maintaining import HS code data.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good question coverage, decent ground truth coverage, low RAG coverage

context_text:
[Resolution]: Use the 'Data Search > Report > Input Status Report' functionality where multiple Contract/Order Names can be selected simultaneously in the search field.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The user was experiencing inefficiency in their workflow as they needed to input each of 6 Supplier Contracts (for Ningbo) individually to extract export destination information, making the process time-consuming for the procurement team. The issue stemmed from not utilizing the multi-select capability available in the reporting section of the system.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Navigate to 'Data Search' in the WisE system
2. Select 'Report' from the available options
3. Choose 'Input Status Report'
4. Locate the Contract/Order Name search field
5. Use the multi-select functionality to choose all required contracts simultaneously
6. Execute the search to view consolidated results for all selected contracts

[Strategic Note]: Leveraging the multi-select feature in the Input Status Report eliminates redundant data entry operations and significantly improves efficiency for procurement teams dealing with multiple supplier contracts.

context_text:
[Resolution]: The issue was resolved by ensuring TTC-Japan Export completed the required registration for the new part number and updating the contract master data in WisE to properly reflect the 1-to-1 business relationship between contracts CNTGT506 and JPNCNT807.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The root cause was two-fold: first, the part number 90183-06030 was showing as "New Contract" in WisE because the registration process was incomplete; second, there was a contract type mismatch where JPNCNT807 was configured as a 1-to-1 contract but CNTGT506 may not have been properly set up with the same relationship type, preventing the system from displaying JPNCNT807 in the dropdown selection.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Verify that contract CNTGT506 is properly configured as a 1-to-1 contract to match JPNCNT807's configuration
2. Ensure TTC-Japan Export received and completed the registration request for part number 90183-06030
3. After TTC-Japan Export completes their registration, CNT office must modify and update the contract master to select the new purchase contract registered by TTC-Japan Export instead of showing "New Contract"
4. Confirm the proper linkage between the sales contract CNTGT506 and purchase contract JPNCNT807 in the WisE system
5. Verify that part number 90183-06030 can now be successfully added to the sales contract

[Strategic Note]: To prevent similar issues in the future, ensure proper communication between all parties involved in the contract setup process and verify contract relationship types (1-to-1 vs. other types) are consistent across related contracts before attempting to add new part numbers.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good coverage across question, ground truth, and RAG answer keywords

context_text:
[Resolution]: When adding part numbers to a sales contract, ensure the purchase contract type (standard or 1-to-1) matches the relationship type of the sales contract being modified.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The customer was attempting to add part numbers to sales contract JPNIDT001 but could only select "New Contract" for purchasing contracts despite having registered items in the Supplier Parts List. Investigation revealed they were attempting to link a 1-to-1 purchase contract to a non-1-to-1 sales contract, which is not supported by the system as contract types must be compatible.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Verify the type of the sales contract you're modifying (JPNIDT001 in this case)
2. Check whether it's a standard contract or a 1-to-1 contract
3. When adding part numbers, ensure you're selecting purchase contracts of the same type
4. For standard sales contracts, only standard purchase contracts can be selected
5. For 1-to-1 sales contracts, only 1-to-1 purchase contracts can be selected

[Strategic Note]: To prevent this issue in the future, always confirm the contract relationship types before attempting to add part numbers, as the system enforces type consistency between sales and purchase contracts.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Decent question coverage, low ground truth and RAG coverage

context_text:
[Resolution]: Contact the TTC Office (SGT) to complete the Contract Part Route master creation for the affected contract.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The customer initially reported an issue with contract THAV1009 (TH-ADVI7) appearing in their todo list, which was diagnosed as an incomplete master registration state. While the customer attempted to add the part number 14118574260 to the contract as suggested, the issue persisted because the underlying problem was more specific - the Contract Part Route was not completed, requiring master creation by the TTC Office (SGT).

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Identify the contract showing incomplete master registration in the todo list (in this case, Contract No.THAV1009 with Contract Description: TH-ADVI7).
2. Attempt to register the target P/N in the relevant contract as indicated by the right-side action on the Todo list.
3. If the issue persists after adding the part number, contact the relevant TTC Office (SGT) with whom you normally communicate to request completion of the Contract Part Route master creation.

[Strategic Note]: Maintaining proper communication channels with your SGT members for master data creation issues can prevent delays in contract processing and ensure timely resolution of todo list items.

context_text:
[Resolution] Contact and coordinate with the Exp country to fix the broken contract master and complete the necessary registration for the part number in the WisE system.

[Technical Diagnosis] The issue stems from a break in the contract master for WisE P/N JJ30100282O, making Contract No. TWJTK801 incomplete and preventing order completion. The contract route was broken after December 2024, possibly due to Exp modifying the master during that time, and the system cannot automatically restore the original linked status.

[Remediation Steps]
1. When attempting to place an order, select 'New Contract' instead of trying to use the broken contract.
2. Click 'Next' and proceed with the issue at step 5 of 5 in the ordering process.
3. Send a request to the Purchase From party (Exp country) to complete the required registration.
4. Coordinate with the Exp country to fix the broken contract master and restore the proper link between the part number and Contract No. TWJTK801.

[Strategic Note] For future prevention, establish a regular verification process for contract master integrity, especially after system modifications, and implement proper change management procedures when modifying master data to avoid breaking existing contract routes.

context_text:
[Resolution]: For contract modification master requests, the buyer PIC must approve the request to move it forward from the 'issued' status.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The issue occurred because the customer submitted a master request for contract modification and was the 1st approver, but the request remained in 'issued' status without showing a 2nd approver in the workflow list. The customer's managers could see the request but were unable to approve it. This happened because contract modifications specifically require buyer confirmation, which was not clearly indicated in the workflow.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Identify that the master request is for contract modification
2. Contact the buyer PIC (Person In Charge) for the contract
3. Request that the buyer PIC approve the master request through the TODO function

[Strategic Note]: Understanding the specific approval requirements for different types of master requests, particularly contract modifications that require buyer confirmation, helps prevent workflow delays and approval confusion.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Decent coverage across question, ground truth, and RAG keywords

context_text:
[Resolution] The master data additions were actually already approved despite showing 'issued' status, as confirmed by verification of the approval status in the system.

[Technical Diagnosis] The customer reported that certain master data additions (DFP SO, SNSS product number addition, and -TTC-MOJI) appeared to be in 'issued' status despite having been approved, creating confusion about whether additional approvals were needed. Upon investigation, the support team checked the master request approval status and found that the requests had indeed already received all necessary approvals, as evidenced by screenshots shared with the customer.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Check the status of the master data request approval in the system
2. Verify the approval status using system screenshots to confirm all approvals have been completed
3. Communicate confirmation back to the requestor that no further approvals are required
4. Reference related cases if applicable (in this case, the ticket appeared to be a continuation of case 240318-000019)

[Strategic Note] For future master data addition requests, it may be helpful to provide clearer status indicators in the system to prevent confusion between 'issued' and 'approved' statuses, or to provide additional training on interpreting the different status indicators in the workflow.

context_text:
[Resolution]: The issue was resolved by verifying that Siradee was registered as an Administrator with access rights to both TTTC and TTAP organizations, which enabled approval capabilities for the relevant Contract despite not being the designated second approver.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The customer reported a discrepancy in the WisE system's approval workflow where siradee@tttc.co.th appeared as an approver in completed registrations despite jolyntan@toyotsu.com.sg being configured as the correct second approver on the WisE screen. Investigation revealed this occurred because the selling price change approval process was set to 'Active', requiring local buyer approval, but the system allowed Siradee to approve due to having administrator access rights across multiple organizations.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Verify the current approval workflow configuration in WisE system showing jolyntan@toyotsu.com.sg as the designated second approver
2. Check the administrator access rights for users involved in the approval process
3. Confirm that Siradee has administrator privileges with access rights to both TTTC and TTAP organizations
4. Understand that these elevated access rights enable Siradee to approve contracts across organizations despite not being the designated second approver
5. If needed, adjust administrator access rights to align with the intended approval workflow

[Strategic Note]: To prevent future approval workflow issues, organizations should regularly audit administrator access rights across multiple entities and ensure they align with the intended approval hierarchies, especially when specific local PICs are designated as approvers.

context_text:
[Resolution] After a request has reached the second approver in the WiSE system, only the approver can reject the request, after which the requester can edit or cancel it.

[Technical Diagnosis] The issue stems from the system design of the WiSE approval workflow, where once a request is submitted, the system does not allow direct withdrawal by the requester. Instead, the request must follow the established workflow process where only approvers have the authority to reject requests at their respective approval stages.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Contact the Global Contact Center (GCC) to request rejection of the request that has reached the second approver.
2. After the request has been rejected by the approver, the requester can then access the rejected request.
3. The requester can either edit the request to correct any issues and resubmit, or cancel it entirely if no longer needed.

[Strategic Note] To avoid future cancellation issues, requesters should thoroughly review all request details before submission, as the system design prioritizes workflow integrity by preventing direct withdrawals after submission.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Very low coverage across question, ground truth, and RAG keywords

context_text:
[Resolution]: Adjust the date range in the Order History (Supplier) search to include the actual supplier-confirmed order date to properly view Revised FC orders.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The issue occurred because the Revised FC orders were not appearing in the supplier's order history when using the Revised FC filter. Investigation revealed that the Order History (Supplier) report reflects data based on the supplier-confirmed order date rather than the PO issuance date. When searching with a date range that started after the supplier-confirmed date (March 21st), the system could not display the Revised FC orders despite them existing in the system.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Access the WisE system and navigate to the Order History (Supplier) search screen.
2. Set the date range to include the supplier-confirmed order date (in this case, March 21st, 2025).
3. If searching for a specific Revised FC order (like MTBA1291), ensure the start date is no later than the supplier-confirmed date.
4. Apply the appropriate filters including the 'Revised FC' filter if needed.
5. Execute the search to view the complete Revised FC order information.

[Strategic Note]: Understanding the reflection timing differences between Customer, Supplier, and TTC-Group order history reports (as detailed in the WisE Order History Reports documentation) is essential for accurate data retrieval and preventing similar search issues in the future.

context_text:
[Resolution] The issue was resolved by correctly setting the order period to August 1 instead of searching from August 26.

[Technical Diagnosis] The user was unable to view internal modifications in order details despite confirming they existed. Initial troubleshooting with cache clearing did not resolve the issue. Further investigation revealed the user was searching with an incorrect date range (from 8/26 onwards), while the internal modifications were made earlier in the month (around August 1).

[Remediation Steps]
1. Verify the correct time period for the order data you need to access (in this case, around August 1)
2. Log into WisE using Chrome or Edge browser
3. Set the order period search parameter to the correct date range (August 1)
4. Perform the search to view the internal modifications
5. If data still doesn't appear, try clearing browser cache:
   a. Open Chrome/Edge
   b. Click on the three dots menu in top right  Settings
   c. Navigate to Privacy and Security
   d. Select Clear browsing data
   e. Check 'Cached images and files'
   f. Click Clear data

[Strategic Note] When searching for order modifications, always verify the correct date range when the modifications were made rather than assuming the most recent period, as data availability depends on when the modifications were actually processed in the system.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Decent question coverage, low ground truth and RAG coverage

context_text:
[Resolution]: Reject the current master request and resubmit it with the correct manager role assignment to ensure proper approval workflow routing.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The issue occurred because part number 09126BZ010 under Contract No. IDITP002 had only a PIC role (randi.hidayat@toyotatsusho.co.id) assigned without any manager role, causing the system to default to TTI administrators (andrezaki@toyotatsusho.co.id, cahyani.anggraeni@toyotatsusho.co.id) as first approvers instead of the intended approver (esty@toyotatsusho.co.id).

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Identify the part number causing the incorrect approval workflow (in this case, 09126BZ010 under Contract No. IDITP002)
2. Verify that only the PIC role is assigned without a manager role for the identified part number
3. Have one of the listed administrators (andrezaki@toyotatsusho.co.id or cahyani.anggraeni@toyotatsusho.co.id) reject the current master request
4. Resubmit the master request with the correct manager role assignment (esty@toyotatsusho.co.id)
5. Confirm the approval workflow now shows the intended approver

[Strategic Note]: To prevent similar issues in the future, ensure all part numbers have appropriate manager role assignments in addition to PIC roles before submitting requests, as missing role assignments can trigger default administrator approvals.

context_text:
[Resolution] The issue is caused by timing differences between workflow setting changes and request submission, where requests submitted before workflow changes follow the old approval routing rules.

[Technical Diagnosis] In this specific case, the workflow setting was changed from "Main: Contract Manager, Backup: Any Manager" to "Main: Contract Manager, Backup: Any Manager" at 00:43:57 GMT on April 29, but the master request (AKM-DNBA, TTTJ - revised details) was submitted at 06:36:34 GMT on April 29, which was before the workflow change took effect. As a result, the approver was set to include both the contract manager and all manager roles under MYT office at the time of submission, causing the approval to route to a manager (Tee Kwang Yaw) instead of only the contract managers (Celine san, Sim san).

[Remediation Steps]
1. Verify when the workflow setting change was implemented (00:43:57 GMT on April 29)
2. Check when the master request was submitted (06:36:34 GMT on April 29)
3. Confirm that the request was submitted before the workflow change took effect
4. Complete the current approval flow using the existing approvers
5. For future contract modifications, submit new requests which will follow the updated workflow settings where only contract managers will be approvers

[Strategic Note] To prevent future workflow routing issues, ensure that all users are informed about workflow setting changes with clear communication about when changes will take effect, and consider implementing a notification system to alert users about recent or upcoming workflow configuration changes.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Decent coverage across question and ground truth, low RAG coverage

context_text:
[Resolution]: Update the contract manager in the contract master and modify the workflow to include a backup approver role before reissuing the master request.

[Technical Diagnosis]: The WisE request for 'SEWS contract activation' was blocked in the approval workflow because the assigned approver (Petr Marek) was no longer with the company, and the system had no backup approver configured in the workflow, preventing the request from proceeding through the approval chain.

[Remediation Steps]:
1. Wait for the technical team to reject the original master request (takes 1-2 working days).
2. Choose one of the following options to prevent future workflow blockages:
   - Option 1: Temporarily deactivate the workflow 'Modify Sales Contract Master' using a UserID with Manager or Administrator access, reissue the master request, verify the contract manager has been updated, then reactivate the workflow.
   - Option 2: Modify the workflow 'Modify Sales Contract Master' to add a backup PIC (e.g., Administrator or any role above the contract manager), reissue the master request, then have the backup approver approve it.
3. Update the contract manager information in the contract master (contract HUSEW001).
4. Reissue the 'SEWS contract activation' request with the updated contract manager as the approver.

[Strategic Note]: To prevent similar issues in the future, always maintain current contract manager information and implement backup approver roles in critical workflows to ensure business continuity when personnel changes occur.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good question and RAG coverage, decent ground truth coverage

context_text:
[Resolution] The issue was resolved by understanding that for new parts, approval requests are sent to Administrators of Buyer Office by WisE system design, not to Contract PICs, until the part is added to the buyer's contract and properly linked.

[Technical Diagnosis] The investigation revealed that master requests (JPNTRT012-1 COGR for WisE P/N: 71501254000) were being routed to administrators instead of the contract PIC because at the time the request was raised (September 12, 2025), the part number didn't exist in the Purchase contract TRTBS503. The part was only added to the contract by Damla Ozdogan on September 19, 2025, after the approval workflow had already been initiated. The blank buyer fields in contracts JPNTRT009 and JPNTRT012 further confirmed the missing linkage between seller and buyer contracts.

[Remediation Steps]
1. Verify if the part number exists in your buyer contract before expecting approval requests.
2. If a new part needs to be added, understand that initial approval requests will go to Administrators, not Contract PICs.
3. Add the required part number to your buyer contract (as was done on September 19, 2025 for P/N: 71501254000).
4. Ensure proper linkage is established between the seller's contract and buyer's contract for the specific part.
5. For subsequent price modifications to existing parts, the approval requests will then correctly route to Contract PICs.

[Strategic Note] To prevent similar issues in the future, maintain updated buyer contract information with all required part numbers and understand the WisE system design where new parts and existing parts follow different approval routing rules.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Low coverage across question, ground truth, and RAG keywords
